caption: Figure 1. MMDocIR comprises 313 lengthy documents across 10 different domains, along with 1,685 questions. For each question, page-level annotations are provided via selected screenshots. Red boundary boxes represent layout-level annotations.
description: Figure 1 illustrates the MMDocIR dataset, a benchmark for multi-modal document retrieval.  The dataset includes 313 lengthy documents spanning 10 diverse domains, accompanied by 1,685 questions.  Crucially, each question is annotated at two levels: page-level (indicated by screenshots showing the relevant pages), and layout-level (highlighted by red boxes around specific layouts such as paragraphs, tables, figures, or charts within those pages). This dual annotation allows for more fine-grained evaluation of multi-modal retrieval systems, going beyond simply finding the right page to identifying the precise layout containing the answer.

caption: Figure 2. Area ratio of different modalities (1) in overall and (2) by domains in MMLongBench-Doc benchmark (Ma et al., 2024b). Note that the white spaces, headers, and footers are removed from the area counting.
description: Figure 2 is a bar chart visualizing the proportion of different modalities (text, images, tables) within documents from the MMLongBench-Doc benchmark. The chart presents two sets of data: one showing the overall distribution across all document types in the benchmark, and another detailing the distribution broken down by seven different document domains (Overall, Research Report, Administration & Industry, Tutorial & Workshop, Academic Paper, Brochure, Financial Report, Guidebook).  The key takeaway is that text constitutes the majority of content, but images and tables also make up a significant portion.  White spaces, headers, and footers have been excluded from the area calculations to focus solely on the content itself.

caption: (a) Avg word length
description: Figure 3 is a combined bar chart and histogram visualizing the average word length and the distribution of word lengths for OCR text and VLM text extracted from tables and figures within the MMDocIR dataset. The bar chart compares the average word lengths of OCR-derived text and VLM-generated text for tables and figures separately, while the histogram displays the distribution of word lengths for both OCR and VLM text across all instances.  This figure helps illustrate differences in the textual information captured by these two methods and provides insights into the text lengths they generate.
section: 6.5 Analysis of OCR and VLM Text

caption: (b) Distribution density of word length
description: This figure shows the distribution density of word lengths for OCR-text and VLM-text extracted from tables and images within the MMDocIR dataset.  It provides a visual comparison of the length distributions, indicating that VLM-text generally has longer word lengths than OCR-text, especially for images.
